required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Behavior Therapy for Insomnia in Primary Care
clinical_study.official_title: Treating Insomnia in Primary Care: A Study of Effectiveness and Dissemination

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical effectiveness of protocol-driven cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia delivered by ordinary primary care personnel (primary care nurses and social workers) in general medical practice with unselected patients, in line with a stepped care approach. The study design was a randomised controlled parallel group design, with allocation to CBT and waiting list control group (WL). Following an active treatment-control period, the control group were re-assigned to CBT. The study hypothesis was that the CBT group would experience less symptoms of insomnia after treatment compared with the WL group. Primary outcome measure was a brief self-report screening form, Insomnia severity index.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Insomnia severity index (ISI)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in sleep-onset latency (SOL)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to fall asleep, measured with sleep diary

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in wake time after sleep onset (WASO)
secondary_outcome.description: Time awake during the night, measured with sleep diary

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in number of awakenings during the night (NWAK)
Change from baseline in Sleep efficiency (SE)
secondary_outcome.description: Time actually spent sleeping out of the total time in bed (%), measured with sleep diary

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in time in bed (TIB)
Change from baseline in total sleep time (TST)
Change from baseline in sleep quality (SQ)
Change from baseline in the fatigue severity scale (FSS)
Change from baseline in the MOS 36-item short-form health survey, SF-36
secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaire assessing physical and mental health

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Hospital anxiety and depression scale, HADS
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report questionnaire measuring depression and anxiety

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Epworth sleepiness scale, ESS
Change form baseline in the Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI)
Change from baseline in the Minimal insomnia severity scale, MISS
secondary_outcome.description: Ultra short screening questionnaire for insomnia

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Insomnia acceptance questionnaire, IQA
secondary_outcome.description: A questionnaire intended to assess acceptance of insomnia

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Body mass index
Change from baseline in sagittal abdominal diameter
Change from baseline in waist-hip ratio
secondary_outcome.description: A ratio of the circumference of the waist to the hips

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in blood pressure
Change from baseline in heart rate
Change from baseline in ALAT
Change from baseline in HbA 1c
Change from baseline in blood glucose
Change from baseline in triglycerides
secondary_outcome.description: A type of fat found in the blood

Change from baseline in sleep-onset latency (SOL)

arm_group.description: The treatment group received manualized CBT-I using a adapted version of a manual designed for use by primary care personnel. Treatment comprised information about sleep and insomnia, methods for medication tapering, sleep hygiene, stimulus control, sleep restriction, progressive muscle relaxation, and dealing with sleep interfering thoughts.
A deferred treatment wait-list condition, with no restrictions placed on the usual care.

intervention.description: Treatment comprised information about sleep and insomnia, methods for medication tapering, sleep hygiene, stimulus control, sleep restriction, progressive muscle relaxation, and dealing with sleep interfering thoughts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fulfilled research criteria for chronic insomnia
Exclusion Criteria:
- other untreated sleep disturbance
- pregnancy
- shift work
- concurrent medical or psychiatric condition that could be negatively affected by the treatment
- drug abuse
- severe depression
- dementia

reference.citation: Espie CA, MacMahon KM, Kelly HL, Broomfield NM, Douglas NJ, Engleman HM, McKinstry B, Morin CM, Walker A, Wilson P. Randomized clinical effectiveness trial of nurse-administered small-group cognitive behavior therapy for persistent insomnia in general practice. Sleep. 2007 May;30(5):574-84.
